The second statement, "It's not the case that the cat must be playing in the bedroom," is the negation of P (not P).

In logic, if we have a disjunction (P or Q) and we know that one of the disjuncts is false (not P), then we can infer that the other disjunct must be true (Q). This is known as the disjunctive syllogism.

Therefore, if "Either the cat must be playing in the bedroom or it's napping on the couch" is true and "It's not the case that the cat must be playing in the bedroom" is also true, then "The cat is napping on the couch" must be true.
